Hi Mark;

Yes to all the above.  Unfortunately a lot were destroyed.

John
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Mark Jaillet 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 10:55 AM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


  Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated at the
  end of the war?  There must have been thousands taken.  Were they
  destroyed?  Brought back to the US?  Mccarthy's basement?
   
  Mark

  -----Original Message-----
  From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
  Behalf Of sigp210
  Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 1:32 PM
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMBERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


  I'd just like to add that the serial numbered swords are limited to
  the NCO shin guntos with aluminium cast handle. I have seen many other
  so-called Japanese swords with serial numbers on the blade, and these
  were almost all Chinese fakes. For some reason, they think this
  increases the value or legitimacy.
  After the war, most of the civilian swords (bar a few identified as
  art objects) were confiscated, not registered.
  There is very little chance of tracking down the original owners or
  history of 99% of these swords.

  Regards,
  Brian

  >
  > Hello David -
  >
  > Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too.
  >
  > If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the
  blade) then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made" sword.
  Sometimes you will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) of a
  sword, usually two or three digits, which in that case might relate to
  "assembly" numbers; these same numbers are often repeated on seppa,
  tsuba, etc. Swords were "registered" after the war and continue to be
  so today, but the Japanese government never required anything
  (registration numbers) to be stamped on swords.
  >
  > Ron
  > STL
  >   ----- Original Message -----
  >   From: dpoll64
  >   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

  >
  >
  >   Firstly, happy  new  year and nice  to meeet  you  all. I am  new
  at 
  >   this so I  have a question that  one  of  you may be  able to  help 
  >   me  with.
  >
  >   After  WWII did the  Allies  make  the  Japanese  register their 
  >   swords and were the  swords  stamped with a serial number after 
  >   registration?
  >
  >   If this is  true,   does  anybody  know  how  I can get  access to
  >   these  registers so that  I  can   trace  the  history  of these 
  >   numbered  swords.
  >
  >   regards
  >
  >   David
